en: Interview with Joe Clark with the College of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology at the University of Tennessee. Clark discusses the black bear population inside the Great Smoky Mountain National Park and how the fire affected these animals. Conducted over Zoom due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is a representative quote from the interview: Animals have ways of dealing with those sorts of things. Things that we think are catastrophic, you know, to wildlife, it's just change, and it can produce, in the long run, it probably was a benefit to the bear population by opening up some of these closed canopy forests.

Interview with Joe Clark, 2020-04-24 -- Great Smoky Mountains National Park
Can you state your name and affiliation with the university?
What is the nature of the research you do and the position you have at the university?
Can you tell us some about the project that you are doing concerning black bears in the Smokies?
When did you first become aware that there was a fire on the Chimneys in the Smokies?
In relation to your research on the bears, how did this fire affect the bears?
Did the bears around the Chimney Tops just ignore the fire before it grew in severity?
Do you have a follow-up project in mind now that you have this pattern of movement?
What do you consider the impact of your research is upon the discipline's understanding of the fire?
Is there any way that science can build upon th research that you've done?
Why were the bears better able to respond to the wildfires than humans?
What would you consider the public impact of this research project? How does it benefit the public?
Is there any other observation or detail that you would like to share with us about the event?
